name: Gear Up
description: Feel the adrenaline as you control your unique tank in multiplayer arcade action! Build your ultimate war machine from over a million different combinations. Now, will you go for the rumbling caterpillar tracks or the crawling spider legs?
minimum_requirements: OS:Windows 7 SP1 64-bit / Windows 8 64-bit / Windows 10 64-bit Processor:Intel Core 2 Duo 2.4 GHz or Athlon X2 2.7 GHz Memory:2 GB RAM Graphics:DirectX 10 or 11 compatible Nvidia or AMD ATI card, ATI Radeon 3870 or higher, Nvidia GeForce 8800 GT or higher. DirectX®:11 Hard Drive:1 GB HD space Sound:Any supported by the OS Other Requirements:Broadband Internet connection Additional:Windows XP and Vista are not supported.

DirectX®:11 Hard Drive:1 GB HD space Sound:Any supported by the OS Other Requirements:Broadband Internet connection Additional:Windows XP and Vista are not supported.

reviews.review_text: As much fun as I had with this game I feel there are some problems that greatly impact the game, before we begin i'd like to point out that I understand what I complain about are game mechanics and I am simply giving my opinion on them.  For a game that encourages creativity in tanks, more often than not you'll find that anyone who has played for a couple of hours will be using the same two types of tank, a gatling tank with tank treads, or a sniper with legs, the latter being the biggest pain at the beginning of the game.  (I apologise if this sounds like a rant) At the beginning you start with a tank with 75 health, with ok-ish movement speed and ok-ish damage. The most common sniper rifle on this game deals 75 damage...see the issue? You can be battling it out with other tanks, come out victorious, and immediately die to a sniper bullet from a tank perched on top of a building, which he got to due to his legs, of which you had no way of surviving. Just ignoring the fact that snipers can cloak anyway to keep their position hidden, you have little to no way of dealing with said sniper...you can't climb the building, you don't have the same legs as he does, and the beginning cannon fires a inaccurate small explosive with an arc, meaning you can't damage him either, leaving him to snipe you again and again happily, or eventually get taken out by someone who can actually reach him. This on its own will spoil most beginners gameplay, as many filled servers will have 1-3 snipers atleast on a team of 6+, yet snipers remain a pain even in later gameplay, simply taking a second shot to kill you instead of just 2. Come on...in a game where you can roam around on a ball of goo with a flamethrower they decide the most fun they can have is standing perfectly still, firing off insta-kill shots until they run out of ammo, climb down the building, climb up, repeat until they either win or lose.  The next is the gatling, which tosses any notions of accuracy out of the window and just spams you with bullets, making quick work of anything that isn't heavily armoured, again also fairly common, and while yes...I understand these are effective builds...it just ends up like games such as loadout, where the 'options' for customisation become invalid and you just rush into battle again and again with the same tank, or try to build something new, only to be demolished by the two 'best' tanks currently, bringing me onto the next problem.  In most games you have something to work for...usually in the forms of levels to unlock more content...this game has levels, but has no purpose to them...they aren't displayed at all besides lobbies (of which you just instantly enter games anyway) and really serve anything more than to give you a rank you really don't care about...which means eventually, you will just be doing the same thing, with the same tank, over and over again, for no reason.  On a positive note, the game is fairly sound, with little to no bugs, ignoring the single time one of my tanks legs got itself stuck into the floor, leaving me on my side until something finally killed me.  All in all, the game is fun for about an hour or two...just don't expect days worth of gameplay out of it, unless you plan to screw over other new players as one of the two tanks mentioned before, but in my opinion...you'd get more goofy fun out of robocraft over this.  Edit: Through the comments i've come to the conclusion that if a beginners league was added to seperate the higher levelled players from the newer ones, this game would be alot more playable.

Pros: -Nice, cartoony look. A brief reminder of when things aren't brown and grey. -Most of your points will come from winning, not getting the most kills. -You can buy any part, any time as long as you have the points. -The parts are very well balanced. Expect to all of them of the course of your play. Well, except for the medic parts. -Many parts are reachable within a few rounds of play. -The starter parts are actually good. Even my super-epic tank of motar destruction has fallen to many a shot from a noob with good aim and smart driving. If you can compensate for bullet drop, you can hit anything and take a good chunk of their health out. -Speaking of, most parts only get overpowered because of the skill of the person behind them, not the stats. When a chaingun tank runs up and turns you to scrap, don't immediately buy that part and expect to do the same thing. -The parts that aren't weapons will range from light and speedy to heavy and tanky, and then toss in a ton of parts with unique abilities. -The weapons are very creative. Every one has it's place where it shines. -Maps are non-linear, leading to situations in Conquest where the enemy is holding out on a tower... Right next to your spawn. Constantly requires that you change up your tactics when things go to the unexpected. -The radar is... interesting. It always shows where friendlies are but enemies are only shown when your radar waves pass over them. Oh, and there's no way to hide from the radar. Stealth missions require hope that the enemy is looking the other way.  Cons: -You don't get quite enough garage slots at the beginning. Leveling up will help, but still. -The sniper guns push a completely different style of play from all the others. The most powerful one can kill a starter tank in one shot. Tankfully (heh) the death cam will point out where they're hiding, so you can remove all of their 50 health from their worthless shells. -No dedicated servers or server software. All rounds are player-hosted. This leads to issues when the host exits and the identification servers tosses out a good game. -Some parts are seen just a little more often than others. -Even though this is the type of game you would want to play on a laptop whenever you have the time, the visual options just don't drop low enough for me.

Gear up is a small game i got to know on a LAN party with a few friends. and to me, it was a BLAST.  so many combinations to build your tank with, so many tactics u can use in combat. at first i was able to fullfill a role as sniper and wreak some significant heavoc on my friends. when they armored themselves too much i couldnt do a thing anymore. because i lacked the correct parts. i then proceeded to buy the game (which i only partially regret, more on that later in the revieuw)  because of my buying the game, it gave me access to all packs and three 'slots' for different tanks. that enabled me to have great fun constructing my tanks, playign with tactics etc. for a while. when my playstyle pretty much settled, the fun decreased. i had nothign new to work for. a rank is nice and all, but i do not feel that in playing the game. it is allmost as if the game is made NOT to be bought.  i will defenitely play this game in the future still if another LAN with friends comes around for example. but untill then, i wont play it anymore, because ive pretty much done everything there was to do, pretty fast everything considered.  so, in closing: try out this game, perhaps buy a small expansion, but if u want to play this game longer, dont buy the full version. (unless they add something to the game that gives u a better progression reward)

Very fun little game. So here am i, halfway down the world to review it. Lets start with the visual part:  Graphics  Shaders, post processing, high-poly models and good looking sprites. Nothing bad on this part. Graphics are great.  Now, what about game balance? Not an 10/10 by any means, but not unbalanced either. Snipers ruin the game fun, they are often very hard to target and with massive amounts of health. Games are often lost with one team being significantly worse than the other one. Not slightly, significantly. I'd give it a 7. Remove those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ sniper rifles and try to balance the teams more: got yourself an 10. Anything else? Advertise the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game. There is nothing bad to it. This game withing an average would be an YES. Vehicle painting seems not used. Because most of the game modes are team deathmatch and conquest, the vehicles are hardwired into red and blue colors. Suggestion would be to let user paint their cars on those gamemodes, but give teammates an blip above their vehicle letting user know if the approaching vehicle is from an opposite team or not.  But yes, let us paint more, remove those mother trucking snipers and maybe a little game balance. Otherwise, i'd give it an 8.5/10. Download it you mongrel. Its free.

What an amzing little game. This is actually the only F2P i can think off that has almost little to no 'grind' (can't even call it a grind actually) and no cash walls (except unlocking more colors). Its simple, and addicting. It took me around 2-3 hours to unlock everything i wanted, the price tags on items are pretty cheap and its easy to earn G coins (the currency that u buy items with) by playing a few games. You get alot of the currency and u can use it to tinker and buy more parts to test new stuff for ur little death machine. Map variety is really nice, ranging from asphalt roads to bumpy dunes, day and night maps as well. Combat feels smooth and great. I have pretty much tested all weapons, and almost all parts:  The game is pretty well balanced, never felt like something (weapon or chasis) is op or broken, u always lose something and gain something in return, depends on how u tinker ur tank and ur playstyle. The servers are stable, i didn't exprience any connection problems with the servers or random DCs in my game time. Other then some rare crashes (once in 2-3 hours if at all) and few players here and there that have lags, i have pretty much nothing bad to say about this game. From what it looks like, the devs are active and patching the games on regular basis.   Worth paying 8.5 bucks just to support those guys.  9/10

There are a lot of unique extra weapons and propulsions, such as rolling around on an alien slimeball, cloaking device, fans that let you hover in the air, and plenty of other fun little accessories. ONe problem that I do have with this game is that the descriptions for the weapons are just plain lazy. The dfull description for the Vintage Jets in the store is literally 'Light'. Lots of broken english in the descriptions as well. I'd like it if there was an update that added actual, full descriptions of all the items in the store, please. It also lags quite a bit if the graphics settings aren't turned down. Otherwise, this game is amazing. 8.5/10

As the concept has been used many times even on a larger scale, this game is awesome. Loads of parts, tanks, many maps & much more. You can make the tank that fits your style. Its amazing how much there is to try and combine. Not to forget that its free, with some things you can buy for real money but nothing that gives any unfair advantage on other players. You can enjoy the full game as much as those who pay for it.  Even beeing killed makes me continously curious on what weapon a player is using, and other parts, that motivates me to try many other parts. Taking the time to actually know how a part works is better than spending all your currency on the first stuff you can buy, needle has to say that I have seen people with six guns, ufo-looking tank... So, anything is virtually possible.   I would totally recommend this game. 9.5/10

There isn't a lot of maps either so you will end up playing the same map over and over again. Also there are not HEAPS of tank parts so you don't get heaps of variety, sure there are quite a few but not heaps. Also when you first start out you'll end up with some lame tank which will easily get destroyed. After a match you get points, with these points you buy diffrent tank parts, but after a match you don't get many points, and, like i said it gets boring after a while. Any way like i said im still a rookie to and this is just my personal opinion, but the game is free so you can give it a shot and who knows, maybe you might like it.

The game is a lot of fun, and it's easy to progress and unlock cool parts. It's also nearly lag-free in 90% of games, which is far better than any MMO I've ever played. The parts available for your vehicle are limited, but have a great variety. They're cool-looking, and fun to play with. The physics are pretty fun to mess around with too.  However, there are little, tiny, annoying bugs EVERYWHERE. -Want to walk on the ceiling with insect legs? Sure thing, but your look will be inverted vertically and horozontallly.  -Found a great sniping spot far above the map? Sorry, that's out of the map and you'll be killed without notice. -Want to play it safe and shoot enemies from on top of a small platform? Nope, physics are too happy so your vehicle will constantly shake/vibrate so you can't aim properly. -Did we mention numerous invisible objects that block your shots and impair your driving ability? These objects are only visible at the lowest possible graphics level.  Sorry for the rant, but it's all the little things that add up that ruin the experience. That said, if you manage to not encounter any invisible objects, and you DO NOT use any walker legs on your vehicle, you will have a great time.

I only write reviews for some of my favorite games on Steam... and this one qualifies. I love the customization, everyone will customize their vehicle to their liking, and very rarely have I seen two of the same vehicle. However, some thing's dont seem right. For example, I built a spider-tank with 225 HP and a large cannon on the front which was supposed to do 60 damage per direct hit. Sounds pretty powerful right? Well, you would be wrong, as a starter vehicle was able to destroy me. Why? He got the jump on me. Literally the only reason. Think of that what you will. Another problem I had with this is the pricing of items in the game, as well as the storage mechanic. In order to build vehicles in the game, you are required to buy items using a currency called 'G'. What is the problem of this? Items cost up to 15 'G' in game, and you will only get 3 'G' per game, unless of course you manage to destroy 10 other vehicles, which will earn you one more 'G'.Then there is the storage mechanic. In the beginning of the game you will only have storage for 6 parts. But you only get storage for 1 more part whenever you level up. Not to mention the fact that, even if you spent 15 'G' on a part you will only get 1 'G' for selling it. Which makes it a problem to try and store lots of items. But despite these flaws, I keep playing it. The game is fun to play, and in the end, Isn't that what matters? Also when it says free, they actually mean free.

Is it buggy? YES. Tons of network errors; odd lag; the linux client doesn't even start for most people; some hardware setups give terrible FPS; graphical glitches; terrain traversing glitches; match glitches; and tons of other minor issues.  Is it fun right away? NO. Unless you buy the higher priced DLC to let you start with all the parts expect 1-2 hours of grinding up for the pieces of your ideal tank. It's not so bad compared to other free to play games with days or weeks of grinding.  Is it fun in general? Definately, YES. The possible setups are widly diverse and fun to explore, and the maps, while few, are varied and interesting. If you can look past the numorous flaws then Gear Up is a fantastically fun game with little to no entrance cost and frequent patches. *( Hopefully we get a working linux client once they iron out non-platform specific bugs. )

Gear Up is an online multiplayer game where you build tanks and participate in online challenges such as battles, races and other missions. The game features lots of weapons, turrets, chassis and tracks that can be put together in thousands of different tank configurations. Experimental parts such as spider legs, hoovers and wings are also available. All vehicle parts are physically simulated and visualized in 3rd person using modern 3D graphics.

Simple yet fun game. Very nice graphics and physics.  Don't know why people say its pay-to-win. By paying you only unlock all colors and unlimited part space as oppossed to starting with 4-7 (don't remember exactly) spaces and gaining a new one each time you level up (although progressing through levels takes a decent amount of time). You still have to unlock the parts with in game money if you pay.  Eventually parts space stops mattering anyway considering that with 12 spaces at level 7 (where I currently am after 16 hours of gameplay) you aquire in-game money at rate that allows you to basically sell the parts you dont need and buy the ones you do with ease. For example: I have 92 Gs. The most expensive part is 12 Gs. In a short conquest match (less than 2 minutes on Oasis) you can earn 3 Gs if your team wins. I can sell an originally 12 G part for 4 Gs (maybe more) and then buy whatever other part I want with all the Gs I've aquired with relative ease.   Your tank only has space for 5 non-cosmetic parts at a time anyway so with 12 spaces you could technically have space for 2 builds. Obviously someone who pays will never have to sell parts in exchange for others but it really isnt much of a hassle to do so and , in a way, by paying you elimate the only real purpose to leveling in this game which kind of kills the fun.

I personally cannot recommend this game if you're just a f2p person.  You're limited to what you can own, and what you can buy. Not only that, those who buy in, and use the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t guns such as snipers who kinda just camp out on rooftops easilly win.  Your starting tank is fine and dandy, and only really good against those of your own skill/level. But there's no true match making or anything to really determine what and who goes where. Instead, everyone has a choice of lobby's. These lobby's only have the name of the gamemode, and a vague range of everyone's combined level. All this does is makes it difficult to say 'well, okay this is a game made for my grouping.' because even if you manage to get like, at least 2 new players, the mass of small crafts, snipers and everything else will -ruin- this game for you.  If you're just starting out and you try and play you honestly can't if you have these players with small crafts zooming around you, making you look like a fool because your tank can't spin fast enough or whatever else might be the problem. I will admit, the first half-hour of this game, i LOVED it, it was an amazing, silly and enjoyable game. Yet, it then showed its' dark side. The community of nothing but stealth snipers and high bloom. Climbers and hovercrafts that zoom around you. The community, ruined this game, as well as the practical pay to win/play mechanic dev's seem to thive over instead of just allowing players to have a simple, enjoyable time and depend on the cosmetics instead of the weapondry to earn pay.

Caveat - this game currently crashes like every 10 minutes.  That said, this is like Robocraft had a baby with Loadout. Pretty fun. Construction and customization is more like Loadout (which is good) and gameplay is more like robocraft (which is good). You get the ease of modifcation and customization of loadout with the moderately more skill based gameplay of robocraft.  Other current issues: 1. Game won't stay in fullscreen mode but you can maximize the play window. 2. It does not recognize all of my mouse buttons in the configuration. I had to rely on some pretty screwy workarounds for changing weapons. 3. Virtually no teambalancer or clientfinder. This can result in some Pay 2 Win situations with overloaded players in newbie games. 4. Games are instanced and it doesn't seem like there are a lot of dedicated servers and it doesn't seem like there is a handoff feature. Prepare to suddenly lose connection to a game when the host rage quits.  A lot of potential here. The bad side of that is that the potential is largely in missing basic features of modern games. It's fun to screw around with for a bit. Hoping it gets polished up soon.

Gameplay: 8/10 +Bots handle very well, and firepower feels just right. +Good physics engine allows bots to collide, fly, climb on walls, and experience believable recoil from massive guns. +Bot customization has a significant impact on your play. Such variety. Many cool. Wow. -Strategy is dominated by snipers. The only way to beat spider-tank snipers is with more snipers. +There are so few problems with the gameplay that I have to nitpick about snipers so I don't seem one-sided.  Free-to-play model: 9/10 +Good overall. Free players level up quickly, earning enough points to buy a new part every three matches. +++No microtransactions that I can find. Seriously, Doctor Entertainment is credit to team.  Uniqueness: 5/10 +The art style is cute. I get a serious micro-machines vibe, which hits me right in the childhood. -The market has robot-building games out the wazoo. Robocraft, Terratech, From the Depths, AirMech, M.A.V., Guns and Robots, and the list goes on and on. Gear Up seems to be just the latest to jump on the bandwagon. -This feels like War Thunder meets Robocraft, but without the customization, strategy, or destruction physics of either. -As robot-building games go, this one really has little customization.  Technical: 2/10 ---The Traktor game engine may offer nice physics, but its performance is a travesty. On a decent PC (80+FPS on TF2), with the graphics all turned down as far as they'd go, the game ran at 15FPS (measured with FRAPS, not the in-game utility, which falsely reported over 100). -15FPS. -Brutal crashes. Don't try to change the texture quality. Just... don't. -15FPS. -Load times indicate the use of hamster messengers for data transfer. -15FPS. +Good audio options. You can change ambient sounds, vehicle sounds, and music independently. -15FPS. +Fully customizable gamepad. About time more developers started doing that. -15FPS.   Summary: If you really like the artstyle and direction this game takes, and that is enough to lure you away from the endless stream of other Robot Wars wannabes, then yeah. Take a look. It might just captivate you. This being said, I can not recommend investing in this game until Doctor Entertainment shows that they can get their engine running better.      -15FPS.

Absolutely crushing curve to try and break into as a new player. Very few lobbies for lower level players, and even those inevitably seem to have some Ubertank roll in and take on people 4v1 no problem.   Game wasn't fun enough for me to want to deal with being a free kill for anyone of higher rank. I prefer Robocraft with it's actual customization, not a limited pool of parts to pick and 'customize' from.  *edit*  Gave it another chance, thinking maybe I just got into some bad games my first time around.  Nope.  Your starting gun is laughably ineffective, and trying to grind out the coins to buy any real upgrades is ♥♥♥♥ing arduous. I played in 6 different games this session, 4 of them I disconnected and got ♥♥♥♥ing nothing, one I lost (and though I somehow managed to scrape out the second most kills, I still got only one medal) and the other I won for 3.  That put me halfway toward buying one of the lower tier upgrades, with the actually powerful stuff locked off behind an insurmountable number of coins.  If I could stay connected, and actually was guaranteed to get any kind of reward for the time invested, it might be worth playing - alas, the network issues make that a guarantee in the opposite direction. You will lag, you will disconnect, and you will get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off.  And no, before people leap down my throat with their 'WELL I DON'T HAVE LAG, UR JUST A FAGET' stupidity, I don't have similar issues with any other online games - 45-50 ms to LoL, 40ms to WoW, ~60ms in Nosgoth, 400ms+ every game of Gear Up.

As far as free-to-play titles, Gear Up is a fantastic vehicle shooter. It’s audience is players seeking instant gratification through combat, who would rather forgo the tediousness of voxel-building to jump right into a frag fest; the type of player who plays Minecraft for the combat.   There are an extensive number of possible module combinations, and it's easy to build new vehicles as it’s like slapping Lego’s together. The toy-box atmosphere, simple controls, and variety of vehicle combinations create a lasting experience that leave an impression. If you prefer chiseling away at the perfect combination of parts try Robocraft, or similar. But if you're a player who likes to smash robots together and watch them explode, then start playing Gear Up.

Ok, without a gamepad, this game is a lot more difficult. You can only get parts from buying them with coins earned from matches, which is just fine. For those who complain that it is difficult to earn coins, my best pieces of advice are to stay near your group until you are ready to duke it out one on one. My second piece of advice is to get good, the basic equipment is good and will last for a fair while. Also, buy support guns first and foremost. just buying one support gun can fill both of your support slots.  This is a fun game with tight controls and lots of fun parts to choose from. (I personally suped my tank up with as much armor as possible. Who cares about moving if you can't be brought down?)
kinda laggy on bad computers and takes hours to build your tank unless you spend 14 or so pounds on premium

Gear Up's customization is very simple, not complex.  Tanks consist of 4 main parts: Propulsion, Hull, Turret, and Weapon and then there are decoration parts.  Some parts grant the ability to add Auxialry parts that are either weaponry or mobility related and you can mix and match AUX parts. There are also accessories and flags, of which some accessories allow for unique in-game taunts.  Gameplay is equally simple. You use WASD to move with the propulsion you equiped, mouse to rotate and aim your turret. You can rebind your functions to make certain functions easier to reach.  There are a few things I must make you aware of though: - There are only 3 game modes; Conquest (capture markers and hold claim to them), Deathmatch, and Team Deathmatch - All games are hosted by fellow players -no dedicated servers. - There is no engine brake; Hovercraft/floating legs will creep backwards. Bug legs will do the same ontop of objects such as on domes, but do not creep backwards from standstill when on solid ground. - There is no feature to switch teams, thus don't expect to make clans (I actually find this a positive thing) - There is no auto balance of teams based on rank, team count, nor kill counts - If ia game is 8 v 8 team and all but one of the other team suddenly disconnects the game is 1 v 8 (happy hunting) and on rare occasion the game glitches and puts all players on the same team. - Snipers are trouble for new players, but so are harpoon+spear builds, builds that run say machinegun+minigun extensions, etc. You will eventually be able to get the same things (no need to pay money) provided you stick with the game long enough and amass G coins to get your upgrades. - G coins can not be bought and can only be earned through in-game participation, victory, or every 10 enemies destroyed -thus the game is accurately classified as FTP.   EDIT FEB 21, 2015: The DEVs have been doing a good deal of considering suggestions and actively updating to resurrect issues (glitches, rendering problems) that were making the gameplay unbearable for a decent number of players.  NOTE: A lot of new players cry that this game is pay-2-win. This is not true. A lot of players who have powerful builds have not purchased BASIC nor PREMIUM. If you do not have the pateince to perservere as a new player and learn the ropes by being tossed about, you will never get to the point where you yourself have a more robust inventory of parts. Every game will net you at least 1 G just for being a participant in the match. You keep your spirit up for enough matches and you will find that after hours you suddenly have better parts, are doing better, and can actually be competitive. We all tend to suck at this game. Come join us in sucking at this game!
